channel.title: NYT > Global Home
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: DealBook: Pay for Boards at Banks Soars Amid Cutbacks
item.description: Banks and compensation experts say the complexity of the business justifies the compensation, but critics say the increases come at a time when bank boards have less power than ever.
item.dc:creator: By SUSANNE CRAIG

item.title: Top Court in India Rejects Novartis Drug Patent
item.description: The landmark ruling, which dismissed a petition seeking patent protection for the cancer drug Gleevec, will allow cheap copies of important medicines to continue being distributed in much of the world.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: India’s Top Court Dismisses Novartis Patent Petition
item.description: In a landmark judgment, India’s highest court rejected Novartis’s petition seeking patent protection for its cancer drug Glivec.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Afghan Debt’s Painful Payment: A Daughter, 6
item.description: The story of how a refugee came to trade his daughter to resolve a debt is in part a saga of terrible choices faced by some of the poorest Afghan families.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: A camp in Kabul. Taj Mohammad borrowed money to pay for hospital treatment for his wife and medical care for some of his children. Speaking of the likely fate of his daughter Naghma, top right, he said, “She does not know what is going to happen.”

item.title: More Diagnoses of Hyperactivity Causing Concern
item.description: Eleven percent of American school-age children are diagnosed with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, and some doctors say that the diagnosis and its medication are overused.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By ALAN SCHWARZ and SARAH COHEN

item.title: Direct to DVD: House Parties for Homesick Jamaicans
item.description: Raucous parties in Jamaica are often filmed, and the footage is sold to Jamaicans abroad who are nostalgic for the sights, sounds and thumping bass lines of home.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH MASLIN NIR
item.media:credit: Michael Appleton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Keeling Beckford, an owner of a music shop in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, said expatriates “like to know what’s going on in the island.”

item.title: Kenya Sees Some Violence After Vote Is Upheld
item.description: The clashes that erupted Saturday night after the Supreme Court ruled that Uhuru Kenyatta was legitimately elected president were nowhere near as chaotic as the 2007 disputed election.
item.dc:creator: By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: People on Sunday in Nairobi worked to put out a fire in a building where ethnic Kikuyus were living. Some protests and clashes erupted after a contested election was adjudicated.

item.title: Harry Reid Draws on Political Calculus as He Leads Senate
item.description: The gun bills that the Senate is about to consider offer a new example of the skill with which its leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, evolves on issues.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER
item.media:description: Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader, holding a news conference last month after meeting with President Obama.

item.title: Found in Newtown Gunman’s Home: Books of Hope
item.description: Those familiar with Adam Lanza have said he had an autism variant known as Asperger’s syndrome, and the police found in Mr. Lanza’s Connecticut home a memoir by a writer who had the disease.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID W. DUNLAP
item.media:credit: Ilana Panich-Linsman for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Look Me in the Eye” chronicles John Elder Robison’s life with Asperger’s syndrome.

item.title: Lessons for Republicans in Hazleton, Pa.
item.description: Hazleton, Pa., presents a test case of whether Republicans risk leaving behind a critical part of their core constituency: white working-class voters for whom illegal immigration stirs visceral reactions.
item.dc:creator: By TRIP GABRIEL
item.media:credit: Mark Makela for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dusk in Hazleton, Pa. The city drew attention in 2006 for passing a law aimed at making life so difficult for illegal immigrants that they would leave.

item.title: South: Michigan 79, Florida 59: Michigan Tops Florida to Advance to Final Four
item.description: The Wolverines took apart the Gators with equal parts patience and raw power, advancing to the Final Four for the first time since 1993.
item.dc:creator: By TOM SPOUSTA
item.media:description: Led by Trey Burke (3), Michigan dominated Florida from the start of the game.

item.title: 2 China Cities Move to Cool Overheated Housing Market
item.description: Beijing and Shanghai announced they would put in place new restrictions and penalties on housing sales to ensure that prices do not continue to soar, fueling what many say is a real estate bubble.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA
item.media:description: In Shanghai, the municipal government imposed a 20 percent capital gains tax on owners’ selling a residence, identical to a tax imposed in Beijing.

item.title: North Korea Vows to Keep Nuclear Arms and Fix Economy
item.description: The North’s nuclear weapons “are neither a political bargaining chip nor a thing for economic dealings,” the official Korean Central News Agency quoted officials as saying.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: South Korean Army soldiers at a barbed-wire fence on Sunday near the border village of Panmunjom in South Korea.

item.title: Khartoum Journal: In Sudan, Archaeologists Unearth Ancient Kingdoms
item.description: Sudan’s archaeological record is pivotal to understanding the history of Africa itself, experts say, and a wave of new discoveries may be adding crucial new information.
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH
item.media:description: Excavation work in Sedeinga, where 35 small pyramids have been found in the past few years.

item.title: Lesser-Known Strain of Bird Flu Kills 2 in China
item.description: The authorities said the two Shanghai men, 27 and 87 years old, fell ill after contracting the H7N9 strain in February and died in March.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA

item.title: Pope Francis Calls for ‘Peace in All the World,’ in First Easter Message
item.description: Before an estimated 250,000 people jammed into St. Peter’s Square, Pope Francis also deplored a world “divided by greed looking for easy gain.”
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Pope Francis rode through the crowd in St. Peter's Square on Sunday.

item.title: Russia Begins Selectively Blocking Internet Content
item.description: Facebook, Twitter and YouTube have been required by government officials to hide some posts, under a law that critics say paves the way for broader censorship.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Andy Murray Wins Sony Open and Secures No. 2 Ranking
item.description: Andy Murray fended off a match point and defeated David Ferrer in an exhausting final that lasted 2 hours 45 minutes in Key Biscayne, Fla.
item.dc:creator: By ANDY KENT
item.media:description: Andy Murray after match point against David Ferrer at the Sony Open.

item.title: Bassem Youssef Posts Bail as Egyptian Authorities Press Case
item.description: Bassem Youssef, a popular television host, is accused of insulting President Mohamed Morsi and denigrating Islam.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and MAYY EL SHEIKH

item.title: News Analysis: Calculating Impact of Cyprus’s Bank Bailout
item.description: The rescue of Los Angeles-based IndyMac Bancorp may provide lessons for what the losses required by the Bank of Cyprus bailout will mean.
item.dc:creator: By LANDON THOMAS Jr.

item.title: E-Commerce Companies Bypass Middlemen to Build Premium Brand
item.description: E-commerce companies are trying to build premium brands at discount prices by cutting out middlemen and going directly to manufacturers.
item.dc:creator: By CLAIRE CAIN MILLER and STEPHANIE CLIFFORD
item.media:credit: Michael Falco for The New York Times
item.media:description: Warby Parker’s Manhattan headquarters includes a showroom. The company plans to open a stand-alone store soon.

item.title: Islamist Fighters Repelled in Assault on Timbuktu
item.description: The attackers appeared to number perhaps 10 or 15, said the French military spokesman, Col. Thierry Burkhard. “A half-dozen” were confirmed killed, he said.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE

item.title: BUSINESS: Warby Parker's Simple Sell
item.description: The stylish eyewear company is one of a number of new innovators that have decided to design, manufacture and sell their inexpensive products directly to their Web-savvy customers.

item.title: Discovery Expands Its Reach Overseas to Ensure Growth
item.description: With a proliferation of channels competing for a diminished number of total viewers, media companies have looked elsewhere for growth.
item.dc:creator: By AMY CHOZICK
item.media:description: “Here Comes Honey Boo Boo,” a reality show featuring Alana Thompson, with Romanian subtitles.

item.title: New Resident Brings Attention to Connecticut Animal Sanctuary
item.description: Photos of a baby Rothschild giraffe at the LEO Zoological Conservation Center in Connecticut are lighting up television and computer screens around the world.
item.dc:creator: By KRISTIN HUSSEY
item.media:credit: Evan Sung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Rothschild giraffe born on March 22 at LEO Zoological Conservation Center, a private preserve and breeding ground in Connecticut.
